title: Case 1
boardPrompt: You are evaluating a 23-year-old presenting with 24 hours of right lower quadrant abdominal pain, fever, and mild leukocytosis.
expectedAnswer: Diagnosis: Acute appendicitis. Key: enlarged appendix, periappendiceal stranding and free fluid, +/- appendicolith; assess perforation/abscess. Management: urgent surgical consult.
rubric: mentions enlarged or dilated appendix or >6 mm
addresses complications (peforation, which could manifest as extraluminal or free air, or abscess, or discontinuity of the wall)
recommends surgery or surgical consultation. Antibiotics may also be mentioned.

title: Case 2
boardPrompt: A 62-year-old with acute pleuritic chest pain and tachycardia underwent CTPA. Please interpret the exam, state the diagnosis, comment on severity, and suggest next steps.
expectedAnswer: Diagnosis: Segmental PE in RLL. Key: filling defects, clot burden, RV/LV ratio, ancillary infarcts/effusions. Management: anticoagulation if not contraindicated; risk stratification.
rubric: comments on RV/LV ratio or right heart strain

title: Case 3
boardPrompt: A 28-year-old athlete presents with acute knee injury after pivoting.
expectedAnswer: Diagnosis: Complete ACL tear. Key: fiber discontinuity, anterior tibial translation, pivot-shift bone bruising. Associated: MCL sprain, meniscal tears.
rubric: describes fiber discontinuity or abnormal ACL

title: Case 4
boardPrompt: A 35-year-old patient is referred for evaluation of recurrent nephrolithiasis.
expectedAnswer: Diagnosis: Medullary nephrocalcinosis. Key: echogenic medullary pyramids with shadowing on ultrasound; cortical sparing. Differential: primary hyperparathyroidism, medullary sponge kidney, distal (type 1) renal tubular acidosis, hypervitaminosis D, sarcoidosis. Management: address underlying metabolic cause; nephrology referral.
rubric: provides a short differential (e.g., hyperparathyroidism, medullary sponge kidney, distal RTA, hypervitaminosis D, sarcoidosis)
recommends further metabolic evaluation or nephrology referral

title: Case 5
boardPrompt: A 75-year-old male presents with acute right scrotal pain and swelling, low-grade fever, and dysuria.
expectedAnswer: Diagnosis: Acute right epididymitis with suspected pyocele (complex, multiseptated peritesticular fluid). Key findings: right epididymal enlargement and heterogeneous echotexture; marked hyperemia on color Doppler; multiseptated fluid collection consistent with pyocele; contralateral left epididymal tail appears normal for comparison. No sonographic features of torsion (testicular arterial/venous flow preserved). Management: contact the ordering provider and recommend urologic consultation and antibiotics.
rubric: mentions heterogeneous echotexture of the right epididymis
demonstrates hyperemia on color Doppler in the right epididymis
identifies a complex or multiseptated peritesticular fluid collection consistent with pyocele
compares with the normal left epididymal tail for side-to-side comparison
addresses torsion as unlikely given preserved or increased intratesticular flow
recommends contacting the ordering provider and urologic consultation with antibiotics

questions.stem: Which is the most likely diagnosis given the provided images and Doppler cine?

choices.explain: Hyperemic, enlarged heterogeneous epididymis + multiseptated peritesticular collection → pyocele.
Infection pattern (not torsion). Antibiotics + urology; drainage if abscess/pyocele.

questions.stem: Which findings support pyocele? (Select all that apply.)

choices.explain: Complex, septated fluid favors pyocele over simple hydrocele.
Supports infection—in context raises concern for complicated infection.
